name: TheAtlantic
text: The allegations of abuse at Ellen DeGeneres’s talk show have the feeling of a reckoning. But a reckoning about what? @skornhaber on the reality-distortion field of fame: https://t.co/uY00EhKyQ6

name: TheAtlantic
text: What will Joe Biden do as president? The pandemic has made it almost impossible to go deep on details, @IsaacDovere reports. https://t.co/I8ukKzDrf9

name: TheAtlantic
text: Intent on capturing an unprecedented moment, many people have been drawn to journaling during the pandemic, @morganhikaru reports: https://t.co/BItuMQEcfH

name: TheAtlantic
text: TikTok is fun, but it’s also trouble—and for more reasons than you might think, writes @ibogost. https://t.co/DWapl2jSPS

name: TheAtlantic
text: We recap three things we learned this week while covering the pandemic—and look ahead to what you can expect as the weather turns cold. The latest Atlantic Daily, by @mimbsy: https://t.co/3ZQJVwOpBX

name: TheAtlantic
text: "There’s reason to believe that such vocal calls for change from corporations could actually be worse than meaningless—and in fact damage the chances that corporations will follow through on meaningful change," Jerry Useem writes: https://t.co/JVHJBb31xn

name: TheAtlantic
text: The new HBO Max film starring Seth Rogen, "An American Pickle," attempts to answer the intriguing question, "What would happen if you met a long-dead relative from your past?" @davidlsims reviews: https://t.co/BfSlyIhTLM

name: TheAtlantic
text: The pandemic "seems poised to weaken the spatial relationship between work and home," @DKThomp writes: https://t.co/IYdzhCd8Vc

name: TheAtlantic
text: "As the economy reopens while the coronavirus spreads, hundreds of thousands of workers are getting back to work, but with less work than they want, need, and used to have," @AnnieLowrey writes: https://t.co/wfng7AiOPJ

name: TheAtlantic
text: It's been decades since doctors regularly made house calls, and they're finding upsides to the more intimate view of their patients' lives they get from video calls, @MarionRenault reports: https://t.co/MOmsHoDbmG

name: TheAtlantic
text: “Regardless of the other responsibilities police have assumed, they have consistently inflicted violence on the most marginalized people in society,” @mychalsmith writes. Advocating for mere reform or incremental change is a moral failure. https://t.co/GzeOiFEg2f

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos of the Week: Back to school in Georgia, a raccoon on the mike in California, Highland cattle in Scotland, damage after the explosion in Beirut, a pyrocumulus cloud in California, cooling in a pool in Spain, and much more—via @TheAtlPhoto. https://t.co/9L8GDjDXre

name: TheAtlantic
text: “Douglass feared that Confederate statues might be erected,” @ClintSmithIII writes. “I wondered whether he could have imagined that his own likeness would stand alongside one.” https://t.co/6Gc7nQYFQG

name: TheAtlantic
text: President Trump issued an executive order banning TikTok unless it is bought by an American company. @ibogost explains why the app will continue to be a problem regardless of who owns it.  https://t.co/clt1N2MkTf

name: TheAtlantic
text: Why is America so afraid of a goofy video app? @MichaelSchuman traces TikTok’s origins and speaks with the founder of the company that owns it about how the app became a symbol for larger political issues. https://t.co/ATszJKGlRi

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @emmaogreen: A couple of years ago, a source mentioned something that surprised me: Pro-life activists were debating the best way to build social services for a world in which they've won: Roe is overturned, abortion is illegal, and there are a lot more babies. 1/x
https://t.co/LV45WOJ1Jc

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @JohnGHendy: "We believe we are coming much closer to a different kind of world, where Roe v. Wade is either unrecognizable because it’s been chipped away or it’s overturned and laws start to flourish in states that reflect the will of the people who live there." https://t.co/SQszdq7mw5

name: TheAtlantic
text: Raven Leilani’s caustic prose is on-brand for Millennial literature of the past few years, but “Luster” also embraces the full complexity of a young Black woman’s story—the good, the bad, and the ugly. @simplylovia writes: https://t.co/d5J6s450p8

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I’d prospered and thrived in the new political economy. And unharmed by automation or globalization or the new social contract, I’d effectively ignored the fact that the majority of my fellow Americans weren’t prospering or thriving," @KBAndersen writes: https://t.co/83ivL1PGvt

name: TheAtlantic
text: As activists move closer to their goal of making abortion illegal, they have started planning for the infrastructure needed for a world with more babies—and recruiting major CEOs to bankroll their cause, @emmaogreen reports. https://t.co/WVEhyCu28V

name: TheAtlantic
text: When her daughter went to college, VaLinda Miller got empty-nest syndrome—so she bought a bookstore, and hired her best friend to help run it. Then they moved in together. @julieebeck talks with them for “The Friendship Files”: https://t.co/ecaAOv14YM

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: these best friends who run a bookstore together are living my dream!

(it may please you to know that after the point where this article ends, there were like 20 more minutes of tape of us just talking about books)

https://t.co/j9ct30jmI2

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: This, by @ClintSmithIII, is extraordinary. https://t.co/WKbboVEZim

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @SStossel: "This is the problem with hollow attempts at 'balance' in our public discourse....Suggesting that Douglass and the Talbot Boys are equally worthy of public memorialization might be 'balanced,' but it is not fair; it is not just." https://t.co/roQ409onbS

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @prashantrao: The US has officially imposed sanctions on Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam.

A good time to read @TMclaughlin3's authoritative profile of the leader who killed her city in @TheAtlantic https://t.co/zUroCVvTZ5

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @SStossel: "Creative destruction was popularized in a way Schumpeter hadn’t meant it, as a celebratory sorry-suckers catchphrase for rootin’-tootin’ Wild West American capitalism as a permanent condition, where the rich & tough and lucky win & the losers lose hard." https://t.co/mvPV7qeSUD

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @SStossel: "College-Educated Professionals are Capitalism's Useful Idiots." The brilliant @KBAndersen on how liberal Baby Boomers (like him) helped the rich rig--yes, rig!--the economy and screw the working class. https://t.co/mvPV7qeSUD

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @TheAtlPhoto: Photos of the Week: Ribblehead Viaduct, Lobster Party, Dragon Splashdown - 35 images from the past seven days, including a rocket launch in Kazakhstan, the Tokyo cityscape, a record store for mice in Sweden, and much more. https://t.co/kXFG4tmntO https://t.co/rZ3uLBATl1

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @denisewills: "Douglass feared that such statues might one day line the landscape of our country. But I wondered whether he could have imagined that his own likeness would stand alongside one, as if they were two equally moral sides of the same coin." @ClintSmithIII https://t.co/iJw034HSTx

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: This is a beautiful essay by @ClintSmithIII:
https://t.co/eREuq4EdCN

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @JeffreyGoldberg: A brilliant piece by @KBAndersen: https://t.co/um1812CEPt

name: TheAtlantic
text: SPONSORED: There's no one-size-fits-all cancer care. Find out how @Philips and @awscloud are using data to help provide doctors with access to first-class treatment recommendations that enable doctors and patients to choose an optimal path forward. https://t.co/Hsa6fz3wWX https://t.co/sV2Qi8K9K5
